questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest X-ray, the following object is seen. Identify? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Button battery

 

Explanation:

 

The image you’ve provided shows a radiopaque object in the esophagus of a child, which is identified as a button battery.

 

On X-rays, button batteries typically present as small, circular objects with a double rim or halo effect. This is because they have a distinctive two-layer structure which shows up clearly on radiographs. The appearance in the X-ray  is characteristic of a button battery, with a clearly visible double rim. This is a medical emergency due to the risk of rapid and severe damage to the mucosal tissues from electrical discharge and leakage of caustic substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coin: Coins are also circular and radiopaque on X-rays but lack the double rim feature seen with button batteries. Coins tend to be uniform in density throughout. Although they are a common type of foreign body ingested by children, they generally pose less immediate danger compared to button batteries.

 

Option C. Ball: A small ball, depending on its material, might appear on an X-ray if it's dense enough. However, it would not typically show the structured double rim characteristic of a button battery.

 

Option D. Bottle Cap: Bottle caps may appear circular but would show irregular edges or threading and do not have the double rim appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate identification and removal of an ingested button battery are crucial due to the rapid damage that can occur. Emergency endoscopic retrieval is usually necessary to prevent severe injury or death.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presents with a weakened flexor pollicis longus and the flexor digitorum profundus of the index finger. Which nerve is likely involved? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

Explantion: 

 

The patient has weakness of flexor pollicis longus and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (supplying the index and middle fingers). These muscles are supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve. The anterior interosseous nerve is a deep motor branch of the median nerve that originates in the proximal forearm and supplies three deep muscles: the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus. This specific pattern of weakness suggests an anterior interosseous syndrome, which is a form of median nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (affecting the ring and little fingers), not the index finger portion. It does not innervate the flexor pollicis longus at all.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve: This is the deep terminal branch of the radial nerve that supplies extensor muscles of the forearm, not flexors. It has no connection to the flexor pollicis longus or flexor digitorum profundus.

 

Option D. Radial nerve: The radial nerve and its branches supply the extensor compartment of the forearm, including muscles like extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus. It does not innervate any of the deep flexor muscles.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Weakness of flexor pollicis longus and the flexor digitorum profundus to the index finger is characteristic of anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, a motor branch of the median nerve, often called the "pinch grip" or "OK sign" deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classical histological feature of Lichen Planus? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Munro microabscess.

 

  • This is not a feature of lichen planus. 
  • Munro microabscesses are collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum, and are a hallmark of psoriasis, not lichen planus. 

 

 

  • Their presence helps differentiate psoriasis from lichenoid dermatoses histologically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Max Joseph Cleft:

 

  • The Max Joseph space is an artifactual cleft that forms at the dermo-epidermal junction due to the extensive basal cell damage in lichen planus.

 

Option B. Civatte bodies:

 

  • Civatte bodies (also called colloid bodies) are apoptotic keratinocytes that appear as eosinophilic, rounded structures in the lower epidermis and papillary dermis of lichen planus lesions.

 

Option C. Sawtooth profile of rete ridges:

 

  • The sawtooth appearance of the rete ridges is characteristic of lichen planus and results from the irregular acanthosis combined with basal cell damage.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Munro microabscesses are a classical histological feature of psoriasis, not lichen planus, which is characterized by Max Joseph clefts, Civatte bodies, and sawtooth rete ridges.

questions.text: The condition shown below can be treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nicotinamide

 

The image depicts a classic case of pellagra, which is a condition caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (Niacin). Pellagra is characterized by the "3 D's": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia. If untreated, it can lead to death. The dermatitis seen in pellagra is often referred to as Castle’s necklace, a photodermatitis pattern appearing in areas exposed to sunlight, such as around the neck, as shown in the image.

 

The treatment for pellagra involves the supplementation of Nicotinamide, which is a form of Vitamin B3. Nicotinamide helps correct the deficiency and alleviate the symptoms of pellagra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not related to the condition shown in the image. Vitamin A deficiency typically leads to bitot's spots on the eyes and phrynoderma (a rough, bumpy skin condition), but not the dermatitis associated with pellagra.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine is Vitamin B6, which is involved in many bodily functions, but its deficiency does not cause pellagra. Instead, pyridoxine deficiency may result in symptoms such as dermatitis, depression, confusion, and weakened immune function, but it does not cause the specific dermatitis seen in pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to a condition known as scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, delayed wound healing, and corkscrew hair. The skin changes in scurvy are different from those in pellagra and do not involve the characteristic "necklace" pattern dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by the "3 D's" (Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia), is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (Niacin) and is treated with Nicotinamide supplementation.

choices.text: Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space
Tube thoracostomy in the 4th intercostal space

questions.text: Adult male, following a road traffic accident, was brought to the emergency with respiratory distress. On clinical evaluation, breath sounds were absent on one side and subcutaneous emphysema was noted. Vitals were unstable. Chest X-ray showed the following. Next step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of a tension pneumothorax, a medical emergency. Tension pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure on the affected side, which compresses the lung and shifts the mediastinum to the opposite side.

 

Key signs of tension pneumothorax include:

 

  • Respiratory distress
  • Absent breath sounds on one side
  • Subcutaneous emphysema
  • Unstable vitals
  • Mediastinal shift visible on the chest X-ray

 

Immediate Management: The first step in managing a tension pneumothorax is needle decompression to quickly relieve the pressure. This procedure is typically performed in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, not the 5th intercostal space as mentioned in the answer. However, for the context of the given options, we will proceed with needle decompression as the primary action.

 

Subsequent Management: Following needle decompression, Intercostal Drain (ICD) should be performed to ensure continued evacuation of air and prevent recurrence. This is usually done in the "triangle of safety." This the best management in this type of condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tube thoracostomy in the 4th intercostal space: While a tube thoracostomy is a necessary step following initial needle decompression, it is not the immediate next step in the acute management of tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: This procedure is indicated if there is a direct airway injury or if the patient is unable to maintain their airway. In the case of tension pneumothorax, the primary issue is with ventilation, not the airway itself.

 

Option D. Tracheostomy: Tracheostomy is not indicated in the acute management of tension pneumothorax. It is generally reserved for long-term airway management in cases of chronic conditions or when prolonged intubation is anticipated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate management of a tension pneumothorax involves needle decompression to rapidly relieve intrapleural pressure, followed by tube thoracostomy for definitive management. Proper identification and prompt intervention are crucial to prevent severe complications or death.

questions.text: 52-year-old man collapses and you are giving CPR with your friend. What is the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult life support, the standard ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers. This ratio ensures that there is an adequate number of compressions to maintain circulation, while also providing necessary breaths to maintain oxygenation

 

In pediatric Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS), the ratio can vary depending on the number of rescuers. If there is only one rescuer, the ratio remains 30:2. However, if there are two rescuers, the ratio can change to 15:2.

For neonates, the ratio is different, typically 3:1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adult CPR, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is always 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a positive Hitzelberger sign. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vestibular schwannoma

 

Explanation:

 

A positive Hitzelberger sign indicates hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in the external auditory canal. This sign is pathognomonic for acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma). Hitzelberger sign occurs when the nervus intermedius (sensory branch of facial nerve) is compressed in the internal auditory canal by the growing tumor. It is considered the first sign that indicates facial nerve involvement in acoustic neuroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mastoiditis: This is an infection of the mastoid air cells that presents with postauricular pain, tenderness, and swelling. Signs include "ironing of mastoid surface" (smooth & shiny look), mastoid tenderness, and sagging of the posterior meatal wall. Hitzelberger sign is not associated with mastoiditis.

 

Option C. Bell's palsy: This is an idiopathic facial paralysis presenting with unilateral facial weakness. While it affects the facial nerve, Bell's palsy doesn't typically cause hypoesthesia of the posterior canal wall. Bell's palsy affects the motor component of the facial nerve, not the sensory fibers that would produce Hitzelberger sign.

 

Option D. Middle ear cholesteatoma: This is "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear. It can cause ossicular destruction and various complications, but Hitzelberger sign is not one of them. Cholesteatoma affects the middle ear structures, not the internal auditory canal where compression causing Hitzelberger sign occurs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hitzelberger sign (decreased sensation in the posterior meatal wall) is pathognomonic for vestibular schwannoma and represents early involvement of the facial nerve as the tumor compresses the nervus intermedius in the internal auditory canal.

questions.text: Through which second messenger system does atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) exert its effects? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. cGMP

 

Explanation:

 

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) exerts its effects through the G+ protein coupled receptor system which specifically activates cGMP as its second messenger. When ANP binds to its receptor, it activates guanylyl cyclase, leading to increased intracellular cGMP levels. This cGMP then mediates ANP's physiological effects, which include natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. cAMP - This is incorrect because cAMP is associated with Gs and Gi protein coupled receptors. Hormones that work via cAMP include ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, CRH, PTH, MSH, ADH (V2), glucagon, and calcitonin, but not ANP.
  • Option c. JAK-STAT kinase - This pathway is utilized by different hormones. Growth hormone, prolactin (which are called "twin hormones"), and leptin utilize the JAK-STAT pathway, not ANP.
  • Option d. Tyrosine kinase - This signaling pathway is used by insulin and growth factors (IGF, PDGF, NGF, FGF), not by ANP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ANP utilizes the G+ protein-coupled receptor pathway, which activates guanylyl cyclase to increase intracellular cGMP as its second messenger system.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome stands for Nevus, Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles) or Endocrine overactivity (such as pheochromocytoma). 

 

Ebstein's anomaly, which is a congenital heart defect characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, is not a component of NAME syndrome. 

 

Ebstein's anomaly is associated with maternal lithium use during pregnancy rather than being a component of NAME syndrome. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Components of NAME Syndrome

 

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not part of this syndrome but is associated with maternal lithium exposure during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an endocrine change associated with protein-energy malnutrition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Low cortisol

 

Explanation: 

 

In protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), the body undergoes specific hormonal adaptations to conserve energy and maintain essential functions. Cortisol, being a stress hormone, actually increases in malnutrition (not decreases). This elevated cortisol helps mobilize amino acids from muscle tissue, stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver, and maintains blood glucose levels during nutritional stress—all critical survival mechanisms during starvation.

The theory of adaptation in malnutrition explains these hormonal changes as the body's attempt to prioritize vital functions while reducing energy expenditure on growth and other non-essential processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low insulin - CORRECT finding in PEM. Insulin secretion decreases to minimize glucose uptake by peripheral tissues and maintain blood glucose for brain function.

 

Option C. Low thyroid hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) decrease, resulting in reduced basal metabolic rate and oxygen consumption as an energy-sparing adaptation.

 

Option D. Elevated growth hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Despite increased growth hormone levels, there is peripheral resistance to its action and decreased production of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), explaining the growth failure despite high GH levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Protein-energy malnutrition produces a characteristic endocrine profile with elevated stress hormones (cortisol), decreased anabolic hormones (insulin, thyroid hormones), and elevated but ineffective growth hormone—all serving to conserve energy and maintain vital functions during nutritional deprivation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the electrolyte composition of 'ReSoMal' oral rehydration salts solution used for malnourished children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Sodium 65 mmol/L

 

Explanation:

 

ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition) is specifically formulated for rehydrating children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). The sodium content in ReSoMal is 45 mmol/L, not 65 mmol/L as stated in option C. This reduced sodium concentration is intentional because malnourished children have excess body sodium despite presenting with low serum sodium levels. The standard WHO ORS contains 90 mmol/L sodium, which is too high for malnourished children.

 

The correct composition of ReSoMal includes:

  • Sodium: 45 mmol/L
  • Potassium: 40 mmol/L
  • Chloride: 70 mmol/L
  • Glucose: 125 mmol/L
  • Magnesium: 3 mmol/L
  • Zinc: 0.3 mmol/L
  • Copper: 0.045 mmol/L

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper 0.045 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal contains copper at a concentration of 0.045 mmol/L, which helps address micronutrient deficiencies common in malnourished children.

 

Option B. Potassium 40 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal has increased potassium (40 mmol/L) compared to standard ORS (20 mmol/L) to address potassium depletion in malnourished children.

 

Option D. Magnesium 3 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal contains magnesium at 3 mmol/L to help correct magnesium deficiency commonly seen in severe malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ReSoMal has a lower sodium concentration (45 mmol/L) and higher potassium concentration (40 mmol/L) than standard ORS to address the specific electrolyte abnormalities in severe acute malnutrition. This specialized formulation helps prevent complications like heart failure during rehydration therapy in malnourished children.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is associated with Acantholysis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nikolsky Sign

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign:


The Nikolsky sign is associated with acantholysis, which is the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes due to the breakdown of desmosomal connections. 

 

 

  • In diseases like pemphigus vulgaris, applying tangential pressure on normal-appearing skin causes the outer epidermal layers to shear off, demonstrating intraepidermal cleavage secondary to acantholysis.
  •  Therefore, Nikolsky sign is correctly associated with acantholysis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Auspitz Sign: The Auspitz sign is typically seen in psoriasis and occurs when removal of psoriatic scales leads to pinpoint bleeding from exposed dermal papillary capillaries. 

 

 

It results from thinning of the suprapapillary epidermis but is not associated with acantholysis.

 

Option C. Button-Hole Sign: The Button-hole sign is a feature of neurofibromatosis, where soft neurofibromas can be invaginated into the skin with gentle pressure, resembling a button pushed through a hole. 

 

 

This sign is related to soft tissue tumors and not to acantholysis.

 

Option D. Oil drop Sign: The Oil drop sign (also called the salmon patch sign) is seen in nail psoriasis, where there is a yellow-red discoloration seen through the nail plate.

 

 

It results from psoriatic involvement of the nail bed and is unrelated to acantholysis.

 

Educational Objective: Nikolsky sign is associated with acantholysis, reflecting loss of cohesion between keratinocytes as seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: Kienbock disease is caused by avascular necrosis of which of the following bones? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Lunate

 

Kienbock's disease refers to avascular necrosis of the lunate bone, which is one of the carpal bones in the wrist. It appears in the classification of common osteochondrites, which are a group of miscellaneous affections of growing epiphyses in children and adolescents. This condition typically presents with wrist pain, reduced grip strength, and limited wrist motion due to the compromised blood supply to the lunate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral neck - Avascular necrosis of the femoral neck is a different condition. In adults, it's simply called AVN of the femoral head, while in children it manifests as Perthes' disease (which affects the femoral head epiphysis, not the neck). The femoral head is particularly vulnerable to AVN due to its retrograde blood supply.

 

Option B. Medial cuneiform - There is no well-established avascular necrosis condition specifically named for the medial cuneiform bone. This bone is part of the midfoot and is not commonly affected by osteochondritis or avascular necrosis.

 

Option D. Scaphoid - While the scaphoid is prone to avascular necrosis, particularly after fracture due to its retrograde blood supply, this condition is not called Kienbock's disease. Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid typically occurs following scaphoid fractures and is not classified as an osteochondritis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kienbock's disease specifically refers to avascular necrosis of the lunate bone, which is one of several named osteochondritis conditions affecting different bones throughout the body.

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ca2+

 

  • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.

 

Option C. Glucose:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):

 

  • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers Pi, uses PLP (B6) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

choices.text: Hip Circumference
HDL
Glucose
Hypertension

questions.text: Which is not considered in the diagnosis of Metabolic syndrome: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip Circumference

 

Option A: Hip circumference is not typically considered as a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. The criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome usually include a combination of factors such as central obesity (usually measured by waist circumference), elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting glucose, high triglycerides, and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): HDL cholesterol is considered in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Low levels of HDL are one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option C. Glucose: Elevated fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Hypertension: High blood pressure is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome. Hypertension is considered a component of metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. The diagnosis of metabolic syndrome involves the assessment of specific criteria related to various health parameters. The objective is to identify individuals at higher risk for these conditions so that preventive measures can be taken.

questions.text: All of the following contribute to the circle of death, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Femoral artery

 

Explanation:

 

The "circle of death" refers to the vascular anastomotic ring formed around the femoral ring, which is critical during femoral hernia and laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery. This dangerous vascular circle is formed by the obturator artery, aberrant obturator artery (when present), and inferior epigastric artery. The femoral artery does not contribute to this vascular circle - it runs lateral to the femoral vein and outside the femoral ring.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Obturator artery: This vessel normally originates from the internal iliac artery and contributes to the vascular anastomosis around the femoral ring.
  • Option B. Aberrant Obturator artery: When present, this anomalous vessel arises from the inferior epigastric artery (instead of from the internal iliac) and courses around the femoral ring to reach the obturator foramen, creating a significant surgical risk.
  • Option C. Inferior Epigastric artery: This vessel runs along the medial border of the deep inguinal ring and can anastomose with the obturator artery, forming part of the "circle of death."

 

Femoral region anatomy relevant to hernias: The femoral ring has rigid boundaries including the inguinal ligament superiorly, femoral vein laterally, pubic arc (pecten pubis) inferiorly, and lacunar ligament medially. The contents of the femoral canal include fat and the lymph node of Cloquet.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During femoral hernia repair, particularly when making an incision in the lacunar ligament to relieve strangulation, surgeons must be extremely cautious of the "circle of death" formed by the obturator and inferior epigastric vessels - not the femoral artery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with an ulcerative lesion near the medial canthus of his eye, featuring pearly margins. Microscopic examination reveals a palisading arrangement of cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

 

This case presents classic features of basal cell carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • Most common malignancy of skin
  • Location above the line joining angle of mouth and ear lobe
  • Medial canthus involvement is common
  • Characteristic pearly white beaded borders

 

 

  • Locally invasive tumor, can undergo ulceration which are called as rodent ulcers with rolled out edges.

 

 

  • Surface shows telangiectasia
  • Histologically shows peripheral palisading pattern

 

 

Palisading granuloma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoacanthoma

 

  • Rapidly growing tumor with central keratotic plug
  • Dome-shaped lesion resembling molluscum

 

 

  • Self-limiting nature
  • Different clinical and histological appearance
  • No pearly margins

 

Option B. Melanocytic melanoma

 

  • Pigmented lesion with ABCDE features

 

 

  • Shows asymmetry, border irregularity
  • Colour variation and diameter >6mm
  • No pearly margins
  • Different histological pattern

 

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • Presents as papulosquamous lesion
  • Shows erythematous base with scaling

 

 

  • More aggressive behaviour
  • Histopathology shows keratin pearls but no palisading
  • Different clinical appearance

 

 

Educational Objective:


Basal cell carcinoma typically presents with pearly margins and palisading arrangement of cells on histology, commonly occurring above the line joining angle of mouth and ear lobe. It is a locally invasive tumor that rarely metastasizes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a second messenger? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Protein kinase

 

Explanation:


Second messengers are small, non-protein molecules that rapidly increase in concentration in response to a primary messenger (hormone, neurotransmitter) binding to its receptor. Protein kinases are enzymes that phosphorylate target proteins in response to second messenger activation, rather than being second messengers themselves. Protein kinases serve as downstream effectors in signaling pathways, activated by true second messengers like cAMP or calcium to phosphorylate specific substrate proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. cAMP: Cyclic AMP is a classic second messenger produced when certain hormones activate adenylyl cyclase. It triggers cellular responses by activating protein kinase A, which then phosphorylates various intracellular targets.
  • Option b. NO: Nitric oxide functions as a second messenger in various physiological processes. When produced, it activates soluble guanylyl cyclase to generate cGMP, triggering downstream signaling events in vascular smooth muscle relaxation and other processes.
  • Option c. CO: Carbon monoxide, like NO, acts as a gaseous second messenger in certain biological systems. It can activate guanylyl cyclase, influence ion channels, and modify various cellular functions through similar mechanisms as nitric oxide.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Second messengers are small intracellular molecules that rapidly change in concentration following receptor activation to propagate and amplify signals, while protein kinases are enzymatic effectors that respond to second messengers by phosphorylating downstream targets to execute the cellular response.

questions.text: What will be the symptoms of a fracture at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anosmia

 

The marked area in the image corresponds to the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, which is located at the base of the skull. The cribriform plate is a thin, perforated structure through which the olfactory nerves (Cranial Nerve I) pass from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

If this area is fractured, it can lead to damage to the olfactory nerves, resulting in anosmia, which is the loss of the sense of smell. Anosmia is a common symptom associated with fractures of the cribriform plate, as the olfactory nerves are particularly vulnerable in this region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoacusis: Hypoacusis refers to reduced hearing ability and is typically associated with damage to the auditory structures or the auditory nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII). This symptom is not related to fractures of the cribriform plate.

 

Option B. Visual loss: Visual loss would occur due to damage to the optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II) or structures of the eye, not the cribriform plate. The optic nerve passes through the optic canal, not the cribriform plate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone can lead to anosmia due to damage to the olfactory nerves. This area is crucial for the sense of smell.

questions.text: Pipkin’s Fracture refers to a fracture of the (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Femoral Head

 

Pipkin's fracture refers to a fracture of the femoral head, which typically occurs in association with posterior hip dislocation. This injury results from a high-energy trauma like dashboard injuries in motor vehicle accidents. The Pipkin classification divides these fractures into four types based on the location of the fracture relative to the fovea centralis and associated injuries. These fractures are serious injuries that often require surgical intervention to restore joint congruity and prevent complications like avascular necrosis and post-traumatic arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Distal Tibia - Fractures of the distal tibia involving the articular surface are classified as pilon fractures or Ruedi-Allgower fractures, not Pipkin fractures.

 

Option C. Humeral Head - Fractures of the humeral head are part of proximal humerus fractures, which are classified by Neer's classification, not Pipkin's.

 

Option D. Distal Radius - Fractures of the distal radius are commonly classified as Colles' fractures, Smith's fractures, or Barton's fractures depending on the pattern. They are not related to Pipkin's classification.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pipkin's fracture is a specific type of femoral head fracture associated with posterior hip dislocation, representing a serious injury that often requires surgical management and carries risk of significant complications.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive weakness that started in his lower limbs and is now ascending to involve his upper limbs. Examination reveals absent reflexes in the affected limbs and no significant sensory deficits. He had an upper respiratory tract infection two weeks ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis of GBS is supported by the classic triad of symptoms known as the "three A's":

 

  • Acute onset
  • Ascending paralysis (starting in the lower limbs and progressing upwards)
  • Areflexia (absent reflexes)

 

Additional supporting features include:

 

  • Recent upper respiratory tract infection (often Mycoplasma pneumoniae)
  • Symmetrical weakness
  • Relative preservation of sensory function
  • Post-infectious immune-mediated process

 

(If the patient had a history of diarrhea, the most likely pathogen would be Campylobacter jejuni.)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse myelitis: Incorrect

 

  • Usually has bladder/bowel involvement
  • Reflexes may be increased below the lesion, not absent

 

Option C. Myasthenia gravis: Incorrect

 

  • Causes descending weakness, often affecting ocular and bulbar muscles first
  • Normal reflexes and fluctuating weakness with fatigue

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: Incorrect

 

  • Presents with upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski sign)
  • Often associated with optic neuritis and sensory symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) should be suspected in a patient with acute, ascending areflexic paralysis, particularly following a recent infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: pH -7.50; Pco2 –48mmHg; HCO3-30meq/l? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

Explanation: 

 

  • pH is 7.5 (elevated above normal 7.35-7.45) indicating alkalosis
  • PCO2 is 48 mmHg (elevated above normal 35-45 mmHg) indicating respiratory compensation
  • HCO3 is 30 meq/L (elevated above normal 22-26 meq/L)

 

This represents a primary metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation. The elevated HCO3 is the primary disorder causing the alkalosis. The elevated PCO2 represents appropriate respiratory compensation (hypoventilation) attempting to normalize the pH by retaining CO2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: Incorrect because metabolic acidosis presents with low pH (<7.35) and low HCO3, which is opposite to the values given.

 

Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis:Incorrect because respiratory alkalosis presents with high pH but low PCO2, whereas here PCO2 is elevated.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis:Incorrect because respiratory acidosis presents with low pH and high PCO2. While PCO2 is high here, the pH is alkalotic rather than acidotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas interpretation, metabolic alkalosis is characterized by:

 

  • Elevated pH (>7.45)
  • Elevated HCO3 (>26 meq/L)
  • Compensatory elevation in PCO2 through hypoventilation

questions.text: A patient with reduced hemoglobin and gum bleeding presented to you. He has thrombocytopenia (platelet count 25,000/µl) elevated PT, and aPTT. Which of the following can the probable cause of his finding? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AML t (15;17)

 

The clinical presentation of reduced hemoglobin, gum bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and elevated PT and aPTT is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is associated with the t(15;17) translocation, is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that commonly presents with DIC.

 

Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL):

 

  • Genetics: APL is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, which results in the PML-RARA fusion gene. This translocation disrupts the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene, leading to a block in myeloid differentiation at the promyelocyte stage.
  • Clinical Features: Patients often present with symptoms of bleeding (e.g., gum bleeding, bruising) due to DIC, which is a common complication of APL.
  • Laboratory Findings: Thrombocytopenia, elevated PT, and aPTT are consistent with DIC. The peripheral smear may show promyelocytes with Auer rods.
  • Management: APL is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), which induces differentiation of the malignant promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AML t(8;21): Associated with AML with maturation, typically presenting with myeloblasts and not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option C. AML t(16;16): Associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils, also not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option D. AML with NPM1: NPM1 mutations are common in AML but do not specifically correlate with DIC or the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) associated with t(15;17) translocation commonly presents with DIC, characterized by thrombocytopenia and elevated coagulation times (PT and aPTT). DIC is due to release of procoagulant substances from the abnormal promyelocytes. Immediate identification and treatment with ATRA are crucial to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: 18-year-old girl presents with bilateral ptosis and difficulty in chewing and combing. Her problems tend to worsen with activity. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatigue of the skeletal muscles. The weakness typically worsens with activity and improves with rest, which is a hallmark of the disease. The symptoms are caused by antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to decreased transmission of nerve impulses to the muscles.

 

In this case, the presence of bilateral ptosis (drooping of the eyelids) and difficulty in activities such as chewing and combing, which worsen with activity, are classic signs of Myasthenia Gravis. These symptoms reflect the muscle fatigue and weakness that are characteristic of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert Eaton Syndrome: This condition also involves muscle weakness, but it typically improves with repeated activity. It is often associated with small cell lung cancer and involves autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, leading to reduced acetylcholine release.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: This genetic disorder involves progressive muscle wasting and weakness but does not typically present with ptosis and the fluctuating weakness seen in Myasthenia Gravis. It is characterized by myotonia (difficulty relaxing muscles) rather than fatigue with activity.

 

Option D. Guillain Barre syndrome:  An acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to rapid onset of muscle weakness and paralysis. It does not present with ptosis and is associated with ascending muscle weakness rather than fatigue that worsens with activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, with ptosis and difficulty in tasks requiring sustained muscle effort being common symptoms.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

choices.text: He is likely to have a deficiency of the enzyme lactase.
Steatorrhea is likely to be associated.
Skim milk will make his symptoms worse than whole milk.
Hydrogen Breath test is a sensitive test to diagnose the condition.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect regarding a child presenting with abdominal pain and bloating after consuming a milk-containing product? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Steatorrhea is likely to be associated.

 

Explanation: 

 

Steatorrhea (fatty, foul-smelling stools) is not typically associated with lactose intolerance. Lactose intolerance is characterized by the inability to digest lactose (milk sugar) due to deficiency of the enzyme lactase. When undigested lactose reaches the colon, it gets fermented by colonic bacteria, producing gas and causing symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, and watery diarrhea. Steatorrhea, however, is a feature of fat malabsorption disorders like pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, or bile acid deficiency, not lactose intolerance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. He is likely to have a deficiency of the enzyme lactase - CORRECT. Lactose intolerance is caused by deficiency of the enzyme lactase, which breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose.

 

Option C. Skim milk will make his symptoms worse than whole milk - CORRECT. Skim milk contains the same amount of lactose as whole milk (or sometimes slightly more), but less fat. Fat can slow gastric emptying and intestinal transit, potentially reducing symptoms. Therefore, skim milk may indeed cause worse symptoms than whole milk in lactose intolerant individuals.

 

Option D. Hydrogen Breath test is a sensitive test to diagnose the condition - CORRECT. The Hydrogen Breath test is a sensitive and specific test for lactose intolerance. After consuming lactose, undigested lactose is fermented by colonic bacteria, producing hydrogen which is absorbed and exhaled in breath.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lactose intolerance presents with abdominal pain, bloating, and watery diarrhea after consuming milk products, but not steatorrhea, which is characteristic of fat malabsorption disorders. Hydrogen breath test is the diagnostic test of choice.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxytocin

 

The image shows a baby suckling at the breast, which triggers the milk ejection reflex (let-down reflex). When the baby suckles, sensory impulses from the nipple travel to the hypothalamus, stimulating the release of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin causes contraction of myoepithelial cells around the alveoli and ducts, leading to milk ejection. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone): While thyroid hormones play a supportive role in lactation, TSH is not directly responsible for milk ejection. It's primarily involved in regulating thyroid function.

 

Option C. Growth Hormone: Although growth hormone has a role in mammary gland development and milk production, it's not responsible for the milk ejection reflex.

 

Option D. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): FSH is primarily involved in follicular development in the ovaries. It has no direct role in lactation or milk ejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is the key hormone responsible for the milk ejection reflex during breastfeeding, triggered by infant suckling.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. It consists of five components: cyanosis, retractions, grunting, air entry, and respiratory rate (RR). Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total possible score of 10. Here's the breakdown for the given case:

 

 

Summing up the scores:


1 (cyanosis) + 1 (retractions) + 2 (grunting) + 2 (air entry) + 0 (RR) = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

choices.text: Improves on treatment of thyroid status
Vision loss may be seen in some cases
10% may be euthyroid at presentation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the given image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Improves on treatment of thyroid status

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), as seen in the image, is characterized by features like proptosis and upper eyelid retraction. The condition arises from an antigen-antibody interaction, specifically involving antibodies against thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors, which mistakenly cross-react with extraocular muscle proteins. This interaction leads to inflammation, edema, and subsequent enlargement of the muscle belly, sparing the tendons.

 

The disease process is not directly related to the thyroid hormone status of the patient. Thus, managing the thyroid hormone levels does not directly improve TED. Instead, treatments like steroids and radiation therapy are used to control the inflammation and reduce edema. This is why the statement that TED improves with thyroid status treatment is incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vision loss may be seen in some cases: This statement is correct. In TED, the enlarged extraocular muscles within the confined orbital space can compress the optic nerve, leading to compressive optic neuropathy and potential vision loss.

 

Option C. 10% may be euthyroid at presentation: This is true. Even though TED is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism, about 10% of patients can present with normal thyroid hormone levels, or a euthyroid state, because the underlying issue is an immune response rather than hormone levels.

 

Option D. NOSPECS classification is used: Correct. The NOSPECS classification is widely used to grade the severity of thyroid eye disease, ranging from no signs (Class 0) to sight loss (Class 6). This classification helps in assessing and managing the disease progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid eye disease is primarily an immune-mediated condition that does not directly improve with the management of thyroid hormone levels; its treatment focuses on controlling inflammation through immunosuppressive therapies.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is in labor, and her cardiotocogram (CTG) is shown. What does this CTG indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early decelerations

 

Early decelerations are characterized by:

 

  • When decelerations are in symmetry with the uterine contractions, the nadir corresponds to the peak of the contraction.
  • Early deceleration is seen when the head of the fetus is compressed in the second stage of the labor.
  • Early decelerations, specially in the second stage of the labor are normal

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variable decelerations: Incorrect

 

  • Variable decelerations are seen typically when the cord is getting compressed. There is no relation between the deceleration and the uterine contraction. 
    • Seen in Oligohydramnios. 

 

 

Option C. Late decelerations: Incorrect

 

  • The start, nadir and end of the deceleration occurs after the start, peak and end of the contraction
    • These are dangerous as this means that there is fetal distress 

 

 

Option D. Normal CTG: Incorrect

 

  • because while early decelerations are reassuring, they represent a variation from the normal baseline pattern
  • Normal CTG shows no consistent decelerations with contractions

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Early decelerations are characterized by symmetrical drops in fetal heart rate with the nadir coinciding with the peak of uterine contractions, caused by head compression during labor, and are considered physiological

questions.text: In triage, immediately life-threatening injury is categorized as what color code? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In the triage system, which is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code. This indicates that the patient requires immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications. The Red category is the highest priority in triage, where intervention is needed within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green: This color code is used for ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment.

 

Option C. Yellow: The Yellow category is for urgent cases where intervention is required within 6 to 24 hours. While these patients need prompt attention, their condition is not as immediately critical as those in the Red category.

 

Option D. Black: The Black category is reserved for patients who are either deceased or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive). This represents the lowest priority in triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code, indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.

choices.text: Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved
Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

 

The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (NOT Anterior nerve roots) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • Thoracic dermatome is most commonly affected (NOT Trigeminal).
  • The rash is restricted to a dermatome, but sometimes a few chickenpox‐type lesions can be found elsewhere. The lesions are infectious
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: False. In herpes zoster, it is the dorsal (posterior) nerve roots and ganglia that are predominantly involved, not the anterior nerve roots. The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia and reactivates there, leading to symptoms in the corresponding dermatomal distribution.

 

Option C. The lesions are not infectious: False. The lesions of herpes zoster are highly infectious, particularly when the blisters are open and the fluid is accessible. The virus contained in these lesions can infect individuals who have not previously had chickenpox or the vaccine, leading to varicella (chickenpox).

 

Option D. Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: False. While the trigeminal dermatome can be significantly affected (especially concerning due to the risk of herpes zoster ophthalmicus if the ophthalmic branch is involved), it is not the most commonly affected dermatome. The thoracic dermatomes are more frequently involved in herpes zoster cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster, commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion, leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes.
  • Herpes zoster lesions are infectious, particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus, and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was started on amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). The patient was later found unconscious at home and brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient shows signs of arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation. Which of the following does NOT suggest TCA poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

Hypothermia is NOT typically associated with TCA poisoning. In fact, hyperthermia may occur due to anticholinergic effects leading to decreased sweating and heat dissipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning can lead to a variety of clinical manifestations, primarily due to their anticholinergic, sodium channel-blocking, and alpha-adrenergic blocking effects. The key features in this case would be:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias:

 

  • TCAs block sodium channels, leading to cardiac conduction delays, which can manifest as arrhythmias. They can also cause QT prolongation, predisposing to torsades de pointes.
  • Therefore, arrhythmias are a common and significant feature of TCA poisoning.

 

Option B. Confusion:

 

  • The anticholinergic effects of TCAs can lead to mental status changes, including confusion, agitation, and even delirium.
  • Confusion is a typical presentation in TCA overdose.

 

Option D. Pupillary Dilation:

 

  • Anticholinergic effects also include pupillary dilation (mydriasis) due to paralysis of the iris sphincter muscle.
  • Pupillary dilation is often observed in TCA toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia is not a typical feature of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning, whereas arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation are common clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby was presented with severe hepatomegaly, jaundice, and cataract in both eyes. The child appeared lethargic and hypotonic. Identify the enzyme involved? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gal-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The condition described in the question is classic galactosemia, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. This enzyme is crucial for the proper metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk. When this enzyme is deficient, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in the liver, leading to the symptoms described, including hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), jaundice, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia. The accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes inorganic phosphate, which impairs glycogen breakdown and leads to hypoglycemia.

 

In classic galactosemia, the symptoms typically appear within the first few weeks of life, especially when the infant is breastfed (since breast milk contains lactose, which is broken down into glucose and galactose). The presence of cataracts is due to the accumulation of galactitol, a byproduct of galactose metabolism that forms in the lens of the eye.

 

 

Galactose Metabolism

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactokinase: Deficiency in galactokinase leads to a milder form of galactosemia, characterized primarily by the formation of cataracts due to galactitol accumulation. However, it does not cause severe symptoms like hepatomegaly, jaundice, or lethargy, making it an incorrect answer.

 

Option C. Hepatic Glucose 6 Phosphatase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes von Gierke disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), which presents with hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia but does not cause cataracts. The lack of cataract formation and the specific features of von Gierke disease (such as lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia) rule out this option.

 

Option D. Fructokinase: Deficiency in fructokinase causes essential fructosuria, which is a benign condition with no symptoms. Hereditary fructose intolerance, caused by aldolase B deficiency, can cause symptoms like hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia but typically presents after the introduction of fructose into the diet, and does not cause cataracts. Thus, fructokinase deficiency is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency in Gal-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to severe symptoms such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia, particularly in breastfed infants.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a documented 20-year history of alcohol abuse, consuming approximately 500 ml of alcohol daily, presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of disorientation, sensation of insects crawling on the skin, and severe agitation. Given this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol withdrawal delirium


The patient’s symptoms of disorientation, hallucinations (e.g., sensation of insects crawling on the skin), and severe agitation, particularly in the context of a long history of heavy alcohol use, strongly suggest delirium tremens (DT), which is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal delirium. Although the history does not explicitly mention cessation of alcohol, these symptoms are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal delirium, which typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. DT is associated with a disturbance in consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, and often visual hallucinations, but can include auditory or tactile hallucinations as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute alcohol intoxication: This condition is usually characterized by slurred speech, unsteady gait, and impaired judgment. However, it does not typically present with the degree of disorientation, agitation, or hallucinations described in this case.

 

Option C. Alcohol-induced persisting dementia: This condition results from long-term alcohol abuse, leading to permanent cognitive impairment, but it develops gradually over time and does not present acutely with hallucinations and severe agitation.

 

Option D. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: This syndrome is associated with a thiamine deficiency and presents with the classic triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. The symptoms in the question do not match this profile, ruling it out.

 

Educational Objective:


Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that presents with disorientation, hallucinations, and agitation, typically occurring 48-72 hours after the last drink

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about behavior change stages and choose the correct answer :(INICET NOV 2023)

 

  • Statement 1: Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking.
  • Statement 2: Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walk considering its benefits to health.
  • Statement 3: Maintenance phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then.
  • Statement 4: Action phase – A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs in his family.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

The behavior change model, often based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM), outlines various stages individuals go through when changing a behavior as given below.

 

 

Statement 1: Correct. Contemplation involves thinking about quitting a behavior, such as smoking, which fits the scenario described.

 

Statement 3: Correct. The maintenance phase describes someone who has successfully sustained a behavior change, such as quitting smoking, over a long period.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Precontemplation is the stage where a person is not yet considering a change. In this case, considering starting a morning walk suggests the contemplation stage instead.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. This statement reflects a precontemplation attitude where the person is not considering change, attributed to a belief that obesity is inevitable due to family history, rather than being in the action phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct definitions of stages of behavior change is crucial in accurately assessing an individual's readiness to modify behaviors , based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM).

questions.text: A patient presents with annular lesions on the skin. Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with annular lesions? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urticaria

 

Explanation:

 

Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is characterized by transient, well-circumscribed, erythematous, and edematous plaques that can be pruritic.

 

 

These lesions typically appear and disappear within a few hours and do not usually form annular (ring-shaped) patterns. Urticaria can be triggered by various factors including allergens, stress, or physical stimuli, but the lesions themselves are generally not annular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: This is a dermatophyte infection that commonly presents as annular, scaly plaques with a well-defined edge and central clearing. These ring-like lesions are characteristic of tinea infections.

 

 

 

Option B. Porokeratosis: This is a disorder of keratinization that presents with annular plaques with a distinct ridge-like border. The characteristic lesion of porokeratosis is an annular plaque with a raised, ridge-like border and central atrophy.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis rosea: This condition often begins with a single herald patch followed by the development of multiple oval, scaly lesions that may have a ring or annular appearance. The distribution is often in a Christmas-tree pattern on the back.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urticaria is characterized by transient erythematous plaques that do not typically present as annular lesions, unlike conditions such as tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: At what age does the kidney typically attain adult-level Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 1-2 years 

 

Explanation: The Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) increases rapidly after birth as the kidneys mature. At birth, the GFR is significantly lower than adult values, typically around 15-20 ml/min/1.73m². During the first few weeks of life, GFR increases dramatically, reaching approximately 50% of adult values by 1-2 weeks of age. By 1-2 years of age, the GFR reaches adult levels of approximately 100-120 ml/min/1.73m². This rapid maturation reflects the postnatal development of renal blood flow, increased filtration surface area, and improved filtration pressure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Birth - Incorrect. At birth, the GFR is only about 15-20% of adult values. The kidneys are still immature with limited filtration capacity, which is why newborns have limited ability to concentrate urine and excrete waste products.

 

Option C. 2-5 years - Incorrect. This is too late, as adult levels of GFR are already achieved by 1-2 years of age. By 2-5 years, kidney function has been at adult levels for some time.

 

Option D. Puberty - Incorrect. This is much too late. Adult-level GFR is reached many years before puberty. At puberty, the kidneys have long been functioning at adult capacity in terms of filtration rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal function matures rapidly during infancy, with GFR reaching adult levels by 1-2 years of age.

questions.text: Parthenogenesis is seen in which of the following worm?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction where the female organism is capable of producing offspring without the need for fertilization by a male. In the case of parasitic worms, this phenomenon is specifically seen in Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Reference Paragraph Explanation:

 

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization.
  2. Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes:
    • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris.
    • Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria.
    • Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichuris trichura: This worm is oviparous, meaning it lays eggs that develop and hatch outside the female’s body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is also an oviparous worm. It lays eggs that develop in the external environment.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, it is also oviparous, laying eggs that hatch outside the body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parthenogenesis, where a female worm can produce offspring without male fertilization, is a unique reproductive strategy seen in Strongyloides stercoralis. This worm is also oviviparous, laying eggs that hatch almost immediately.

questions.text: Following vasectomy, the man is advised to use additional contraception till when? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 months

 

Following a vasectomy procedure, men must use additional contraception for 3 months. After this period, they are called back for a semen analysis. Only after documenting azoospermia (complete absence of sperm in the semen) should they be given a certificate confirming sterility. This waiting period is necessary to ensure all remaining sperm have been cleared from the reproductive tract.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Following vasectomy, additional contraception must be used for 3 months until azoospermia is confirmed by semen analysis.

choices.text: Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli

questions.text: Where is the most common site for a venous ulcer to develop? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli 

 

Explanation:

 

Venous ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle. The majority of ulcers develop on the medial side of the calf below the malleoli. This is the region where many of the Cockett perforators join the posterior tibial vein to the posterior arch vein (superficial vein). The chronic venous hypertension in this area leads to tissue damage and eventually ulceration when exposed to high venous and capillary pressures chronically.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli: While ulcers associated with short saphenous vein incompetence may develop on the lateral side of the leg, they are less common than medial ulcers.
  • Option C. Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli: Venous ulcers rarely extend into the upper calf, and this location would be uncommon.
  • Option D. Medial aspect of the thigh: Venous ulcers typically occur below the malleoli in the gaiter area rather than thigh.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Venous ulcers most commonly occur on the medial aspect of the ankle below the malleoli (gaiter area) due to the presence of perforating veins and high venous pressure in this region, especially in patients with chronic venous insufficiency.

questions.text: A 2 month pregnant female presents with swelling in legs and diagnosed with Deep vein thrombosis, she requires anticoagulation. Which of the following is Preferred?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enoxaparin

 

Explanation

 

In pregnant women diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as enoxaparin is the preferred anticoagulant.

 

LMWH is effective and has a better safety profile for both the mother and the fetus compared to other anticoagulants.

 

Warfarin is teratogenic and contraindicated in pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) like apixaban are not recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. Aspirin alone is not effective for treating DVT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: This is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects.

 

Option B. Apixaban: DOACs are not approved for use in pregnant or lactating women due to a lack of sufficient safety data.

 

Option D. Aspirin: While it may be used for certain cardiovascular conditions, it is not effective as a sole agent for the treatment of DVT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enoxaparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for pregnant women with DVT due to its safety and effectiveness, whereas warfarin, DOACs, and aspirin are not appropriate choices in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Pediatric Assessment Triangle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Heart Rate

 

Explanation: 

 

The Pediatric Assessment Triangle (PAT) is a rapid visual assessment tool used in pediatric emergencies that consists of exactly three components. These components allow for quick evaluation without touching the patient or using equipment. Heart rate is not part of the PAT as it cannot be visually assessed and requires physical examination with a stethoscope or monitoring equipment. Heart rate is instead evaluated during the subsequent hands-on assessment after the initial PAT is completed.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. General Appearance - This is a correct component of the PAT. It includes assessment of the child's tone, interactivity, consolability, look/gaze, and speech/cry to rapidly determine the child's overall status and level of distress.

 

Option B. Breathing Effort - This is a correct component of the PAT. It involves assessment of airway patency and breathing adequacy through observation of positioning, retractions, flaring, and audible breathing sounds.

 

Option C. Skin Circulation - This is a correct component of the PAT. It involves visual assessment of skin color (pale, mottled, cyanotic) and overall perfusion without touching the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pediatric Assessment Triangle is a rapid visual assessment tool consisting of only three components: general appearance, breathing effort, and circulation to skin - allowing for immediate categorization of severity and type of illness without equipment or physical contact.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs decreases the serum parathyroid hormone levels? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitriol

 

Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D and plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate metabolism in the body. It directly acts on vitamin D receptors (VDRs) present in the parathyroid gland, leading to a decrease in the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Mechanism of Action: Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium and phosphate from the intestines. Elevated levels of calcium in the blood provide negative feedback to the parathyroid glands, which reduces the production of PTH. Additionally, calcitriol directly inhibits the synthesis and secretion of PTH by binding to VDRs in the parathyroid gland. This dual action ensures a reduction in PTH levels, making calcitriol an effective treatment for conditions associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Note - Paricalcitol: A synthetic vitamin D receptor (VDR) agonist used to reduce PTH levels in primary hyperparathyroidism. This drug is related to the Cinacalcet, a calcium sensitizer but this act on the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risedronate: Risedronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis. It works by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, which can sometimes lead to hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can reflexively increase PTH levels, rather than decrease them.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium is known to cause unexplained hyperparathyroidism and consequently increase PTH levels. It is one of the common causes of unexplained hyperparathyroidism, making it an unsuitable option for decreasing PTH levels.

 

Option D. Diuretics: Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can cause hypocalcemia, which in turn can lead to an increase in PTH levels. Thiazide diuretics can cause hypercalcemia, which might decrease PTH levels, but in this question, "diuretics" is mentioned generally, and loop diuretics are more commonly associated with increased PTH levels due to hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:
