Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, decreases serum parathyroid hormone levels by increasing calcium absorption from the intestines and directly inhibiting PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands through its action on vitamin D receptors.

questions.text: Diagnose the X-ray as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteosarcoma


Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that typically shows characteristic radiographic features such as the "sunburst" or "sun ray" appearance, which is caused by the tumor's aggressive growth pattern. In addition to this, Codman’s triangle may be visible, which occurs when the tumor lifts the periosteum off the bone, forming a triangular area of new bone formation. The lower end of the femur is a common site for osteosarcoma, as well as other long bones in the body.

 

In the provided X-rays, the sun ray appearance is clearly visible, making osteosarcoma the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondroblastoma: This tumor typically presents with calcifications in the epiphyseal (end) regions of bones, particularly in the upper end of the humerus. However, chondroblastoma does not present with a sun ray appearance.

 

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma: This is another malignant tumor, but it primarily affects the upper end of the femur or pelvis. The X-ray for chondrosarcoma typically shows dense calcifications, but not the sun ray pattern associated with osteosarcoma.

 

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: This tumor often presents with a diaphyseal (shaft) lesion in long bones and can cause an "onion-skin" appearance due to the layered periosteal reaction. It does not exhibit the sun ray pattern seen in osteosarcoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The sun ray appearance and Codman’s triangle in X-rays are key indicators of osteosarcoma, especially in the lower end of long bones like the femur.

questions.text: Identify the congenital abnormality shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Open Neural Tube Defect

 

The image shows an open neural tube defect (ONTD) where there is complete non-closure of the neural tube during embryonic development. It specifically shows anterior neuropore defect characterized by:

 

  • Absent cranial vault
  • Exposed neural tissue
  • Exophthalmos (prominent eyes)
  • Chin resting on chest This represents a severe form of neural tube defect where both anterior and posterior neuropores have failed to close by day 28 of embryonic development.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myelomeningocele: While this is also a neural tube defect, it specifically refers to protrusion of spinal cord and meninges through a defect in vertebral column. The image shows a more extensive defect.

 

Option B. Spina bifida occulta: This is a mild form where vertebral arches fail to fuse but spinal cord remains intact and covered by skin. The image shows exposed neural tissue.

 

 

Option C. Anencephaly: A failure of the cranial neuropore to close, leading to absence of the skull and most of the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Open Neural Tube Defects (ONTDs) result from incomplete closure of the neural tube during early development. They can manifest in various forms, including myelomeningocele and anencephaly, depending on the site of the defect. Adequate maternal folate supplementation is critical for reducing the risk of ONTDs.

choices.text: Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism
Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with proximal weakness, lethargy, low/depressed mood, and recurrent renal stones. Laboratory testing revealed a normal S. Calcium and increased PTH levels. What is the organ involved and the pathology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism

 

The clinical presentation of proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones, combined with laboratory findings of normal serum calcium and increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, is indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is typically associated with hypercalcemia, but there is a variant known as normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism. In this condition, patients exhibit elevated PTH levels while maintaining normal serum calcium levels.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Proximal Weakness and Lethargy: Common symptoms of hyperparathyroidism due to muscle weakness and fatigue.
  • Low/Depressed Mood: Psychiatric manifestations are frequently seen in hyperparathyroidism.
  • Recurrent Renal Stones: Hyperparathyroidism leads to increased calcium excretion, resulting in kidney stones.
  • Normal Serum Calcium and Increased PTH: In normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated, but serum calcium levels remain within the normal range.

 

This condition is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism (e.g., vitamin D deficiency, chronic kidney disease) must be ruled out first. Given the absence of clinical findings suggesting vitamin deficiency, osteomalacia, or chronic kidney disease in this case, normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid and Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism does not present with the combination of symptoms and laboratory findings described.

 

Option C. Adrenal and Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma typically presents with episodic hypertension, headaches, and palpitations, not the symptoms and lab findings described.

 

Option D. Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease: While metabolic bone diseases can cause weakness and other symptoms, they do not typically present with elevated PTH and normal calcium as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism presents with normal serum calcium and elevated PTH levels and is associated with symptoms like proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones. It is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Under categorization of triage, the immediately life-threatening injuries would be classified as under the color-coded category: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Red

 

The triage system is used in disaster management to categorize victims based on the severity of their condition and the likelihood of survival. Immediate life-threatening injuries, where a person could die or develop severe complications if no intervention is made within 0 to 6 hours, are classified under the Red category. This category is designated for emergent cases that require immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This category is for urgent cases where intervention is needed within 6 to 24 hours, such as resuscitation or limb/life-saving surgery. Although these injuries are serious, they are not as immediately life-threatening as those in the Red category.

 

Option C. Green: This category is for non-urgent cases involving minor injuries like fractures, bruises, or lacerations. Patients in this category are ambulatory and can wait for treatment.

 

Option D. Black: This category is for patients who are either deceased or moribund (about to die). It represents the least priority in triage, as these patients have little to no chance of survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage Tagging system
